discourse_list.title: The United States Court of Appeals (5th Circuit) : SEC in-house adjudication violates 7th Amendment right to trial by jury

content.content: ca5.uscourts.gov    20-61007-CV0.pdf 324.57 KB      While the decision is still likely subject to an en banc review from the entire 5th Circuit Court of Appeals, this is a blow to the SEC administrative adjudication process. In theory, if this decision holds up, the SEC would have to provide a jury for all in-house administrate proceedings which will present challenges from an operational standpoint. Not to mention, instead of an administrate law judge deciding the matter, the finders of fact would be ordinary individuals sitting for jury duty. This decision also could have far reaching implications beyond the realm of the SEC. For example, there are many other administrative proceedings that involve, potentially, someone’s liberty and freedom, which do not provide a right to a jury, including New York State Department of Motor Vehicle administrative proceedings, Child Protective Services proceedings, as well as Department of Correction disciplinary proceedings, to name a few. Why does this matter you may ask ? Well, if you ever find yourself in such a scenario in front of a regulatory body, you might want ordinary people deciding your fate, or,  you may want to waive that right and have an appointed political bureaucrat make the decisions. Either way, giving an individual the right to a jury allows that person (and presumably their counsel) to make a tactical informed decision, and that is very important.

This decision is good for democracy. In theory, jury is one of the best institutions for democracy. The experience of serving empowers the jurors and enhances civic consciousness. However, juries are expensive. Personally, I have tried to avoid jury service because of the time demands and token compensation.

Yes. The decision also held that congress unconstitutionally delegated legislative power to the SEC and the Take Care Clause in Article II of the Constitution was violated. As to the jury trial aspect, the court held that the Seventh Amendment guarantees  a jury trial because the SEC’s enforcement action is akin to traditional actions at law to which the jury-trial right attaches. It makes sense.
Real question is how the Supreme Court will handle this. Its a difficult ruling for them to not review as it has broad implications for future cases

Yes, if they want to hear it. There will likely be an en banc review first and a subsequent petition for cert. if the decision is upheld by the entire circuit court of appeals. There is a dissent as well. It doesn’t seem to be the strongest argument but an argument nonetheless.
